bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, February 11, 1924

div1.p: [Carter] writes about the insect vector disease theory and about the controversy between Carlos Finlay and Walter Reed.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, February 11, 1924
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Finlay
/LC
2121 California St., N. W,
Washington, D. C.,
February 11, 1924.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Much obliged to you for the clipping by young Dr. Finlay
just received.

Both Finlay and Guiteras felt that Finlay's work had been
insufficiently recognized as, indeed, did Gorgas and myself. In
fact Guiteras made rather a sharp attack on Osler for leaving Fin-
lay's name out in a paper he wrote some time (probably ten years) ago
on the insect conveyance of disease. My view of the matter, as
well as I could express it, you will find on the first page or two
of the article on yellow fever in the “Practise of Medicine in the
Tropics”: Oxford Press.

So far as the “discovery” that George Finlay claims is con-
cerned, it is a question of the use of the word. Had Columbus dis-
covered that the world was round when he sailed from Palos, or was this
left to Magellan, or possibly Balboa? Columbus formulated this
statement and was absolutely convinced of it, but had not demon-
strated it, at that time: Finlay announced the mosquito convey-
ance and was absolutely convinced of it--I do not believe Reed's
experiments added an iota to his certainty of it; as I think Colum-
Colum-
-2-
bus would have been surprised if he had not run up upon his “Ci-
pango.” Finlay had data that was absolutely convincing to himself,
as had Columbus--and the convictions in both cases were right--in
neither case, however, had this data convinced the rest of the world.
I doubt if Columbus had stopped at Palos whether he would have been
considered the discoverer of the rotundity of the earth.

To what extent Reed was influenced by Finlay's theory I do
not know. He always said in no way, which seems scarcely credible.
He declined to let me explain it to him when I visited him at Que-
mados. the Fourth of July, 1899, as he said he did not wish to be
biased by anyone' else's opinion. I will say this though, that if I
had read all that Finlay had written up to that time, I would have
considered it as “establishing so strong an antecedent probability”
for his views that I would have begged for an experimental try-out.
Frankly, I think that my own work in determining the existence of
the “period of extrinsic incubation of yellow fever,” taken with
Ronald Ross' on the conveyance of malaria determined the direction
of his experimentation. He practically says this in his first
paper. and did so repeatedly in letters and conversations.

The quotation from Dr. Carlos Finlay given in the clipping
is, I have no doubt, true. It is just what he would have said and
felt. He was one of the kindest, fairest and most unselfish men
I have known.
Again thanking you for the clipping,
